body:
Thank you for your reply and your help. 
We will try to update our superset version.

> Using mysql? Tried setting the charset on the connection string as in mysql://user:password@1.1.1.1/db?charset=utf8? @mistercrunch 

this can fix dashboard show record, however, slice show record is still 500 error

Thanks. For the benefit of anyone else looking for a similar solution: I replaced my existing patches with one adding the footer inclusion code to the `basic.html` file as suggested. It appears to be sufficient but I have not had a chance to test all sections. 

I am happy for the issue to be closed if you do not intend to implement footer support in project-specific templates.

Hi Team , 
Any update on this ..
This has already been fixed in a released version and there's already a duplicate issue #4685 open. Please close.

@xrmx Yup. I just opened one [here](https://github.com/LocusEnergy/sqlalchemy-vertica-python/issues/12), since it is dependent on which Vertica dialect you are using, and that is the one recommended in the docs.
removed the [WiP] tag, this is ready for review
LGTM

@mistercrunch even though in `sql_lab.py` [get_sqla_engine](https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/blob/master/superset/sql_lab.py#L209) is called with the `user_name` parameter, the Jinja template issue we're seeing is when one is using `presto.latest_partition` which doesn't pass through the username, and from reading through the code this may neither be feasible nor non-trivial.

How do you feel about the change? Note I'm somewhat perplex how other portions of `execute_sql` work on a Celery worker like [get_session](https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/blob/master/superset/sql_lab.py#L81) which references `app` as I presume that would also be working outside of an app context.

Not reporter, but similar experience, using the community docker image as a base, but shifting to version 0.24.0 (direct pull from github releases as it wasn't available on pypi this morning)

HTML Fails to pull a reference in the header:
`<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="/static/assets/dist/" />
` 

Which to source is 
`      <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="{{ js_manifest('theme.css') }}" />
`
in templates/superset/basic.html.

I started to try to trace js_manifest, but couldn't find a generated manifest that it was trying to read, or how to generate one, so I started checking in the issues list here on github, and here I am 😄

Approximate patch, will likely need fuzzy to apply

```
diff --git a/docker/superset/Dockerfile b/docker/superset/Dockerfile
index d0d1e0a..b573aa4 100644
--- a/docker/superset/Dockerfile
+++ b/docker/superset/Dockerfile
@@ -3,3 +3,3 @@ FROM ...
 # Superset version
-ARG SUPERSET_VERSION=0.23.3
+ARG SUPERSET_VERSION=0.24.0
 
@@ -49,3 +49,3 @@ RUN useradd -U -m superset && \
         Werkzeug==0.12.1 \
-        superset==${SUPERSET_VERSION}
+        https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/archive/${SUPERSET_VERSION}.tar.gz
```
@jdnurmi That would mean that the package uploaded to pypi is broken.
Sorry, to be clear, there isn't a 0.24.0 on pypi yet - this is using the version in the github releases directly via pip install that looks to have shipped late last week.

After talking with Chris a bit more about this, for now I think we are just going to use `react-virtualized` until there's a clear need to use something within `data-ui/data-table`.

I'm going to start by moving the Table viz over to react-virtualized.

I have solved this problem. I am using py2. 
1. you should fix mysql url by `mysql://user:password@1.1.1.1/db?charset=utf8`
2. if you are using py2, you should specify 
```
if sys.version_info.major < 3:
    reload(sys)
sys.setdefaultencoding('utf8')
```
and then things works ☄️

Just realized that refactoring the views to a new location will break permissions. Now I'm debating whether to move the views back to their original location or writing a db migration script to update the perms.
There was an issue with `setup.py` getting in the way of publishing the release. It's out now. I haven't published the changelog yet though.
@yamyamyuo that's not a fix, which version are you using?

If visual consistency (before and after) is a requirement it will be much harder to achieve with `react-virtualized`.  With `reactable` it will be fairly easy to get the same effective html `<Table>`. 

With  `react-virtualized` you'll have to mimic dynamic column sizing based on content, and will either have to overflow or do guesswork to force proportions and wrapping based on column content.
https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#setting-up-the-node--npm-javascript-environment
I just pushed `0.24.0` to pypi and a PR with the changelog

I also met the same question when upgraded from 0.22.1 to 0.23.2 .  All the slices in my more than 50 dashboards are all zoomed after upgraded as yours. Expect this will be solved as soon as possible.

It's a bit hard to read the PR since Github doesn't highlight the right lines at all here. Crazy how an indent completely confuses their diffing function.

But even with the Flask context manager you still won't get the user info I'm guessing as the user is not authenticated on the celery side of things. I guess it just fixes that error, but probably does not impersonate the right user deep down the call stack.

There should not be an app context at that point, so my thought is we have to clean up the reliance on `g.user` and pass it down the stack instead.

1) look for file 'config.py' in your superset environment:
File path on my server:
/root/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/superset/config.py
2)search "encoding" in this file and modify that line into:
'encoding': 'gb18030',
the default encoding mode is utf-8, but default encoding in office is GB. This is the root cause.
3) restart your superset service. Good luck.

Right!
I have success set up.

I followed up all of the both section
(but did not use "Copies a conf file from the frontend to the backend", "Compiles the production / optimized js & css". I do not know the purpose of them.)

Then I tried
$ superset runserver -d -p 8081
$ npm run dev

So my problem is cleaned up! Thank you a lot!
I will close this Issue
Thanks!

Seems like the template processor needs to be aware of the `username` and the calls in `db_engine_specs` should relay the username to calls that interact with the engine in `models.py`.

Passing it through gets pretty deep and nasty. Maybe mimicking the Flask app context isn't a bad idea, but I'm unclear on how to do that.

At first I thought "would it be crazy would the celery worker to call REST endpoints?" That's probably a very bad idea.

Now I'm thinking "how about doing the template rendering ahead of time in the web request and putting the rendered template in the db for the worker to run?".

Run the database migration scripts. It's in the upgrade instructions:
https://superset.incubator.apache.org/installation.html#upgrading
It should be in 0.24.0
Thanks... 0.24.0 is now applied.

@mistercrunch I also raised the idea of pre-computing information on the Flask server which is inline with your last comment.

I sense the Celery worker should be app agnostic and simply run the query.

`Table clusters already exists` is a weird issue since `clusters` is a table that was added really early on in the project. Have you been issuing alembic related commands? Altering the `alembic_version` table?

Agreed, it took me a moment to catch up with your thinking process. Had to go through similar reasoning.

For context at the time where the decision was made to process the template on the worker, there was no impersonation going on, and it somewhat made sense to do more work on the worker. At this point I think it makes sense to render the template on the web server. It shouldn't affect query time, only pending time may appear a little longer.
Sounds like this is an issue for Flask-AppBuilder.

Attn: @claycrosby @jkokatjuhha I am unable to to replicate this bug; have you tested against a fresh version? If it's still present I can work on this issue if someone can help me reproduce the problem.
@mistercrunch @john-bodley Done!

@mistercrunch @michellethomas thanks for the reviews! I addressed all comments.

For Max's more in depth comments:
- enabled adhoc metrics on the `metric` controller. Required adding some additional case statements in the MetricsControl component where I assume `value` will be an array. Also required some small style updates.
- for making it more clear that the tokens are editable, I had the AdhocMetricEditPopover appear by default when a new metric is created. I also updated the default text in the select component.

I also added another feature that HIDES any auto generated metric that is just an aggregate + column.

Please take another look when you have the chance!

We have users adding tables with large amounts of data to dashboards (that then freeze or slow down the dashboard), I'm hoping we see some performance improvements moving to `react-virtualized`, but if I can't get it to work I'll use reactable.

Sure, it is the same as the sql passed above `SELECT firstname, lastname FROM bf_raw.bf_user where firstname like 'A%' limit 10', just seems to be a problem with pyscopg2 and pandas.

To overcome this I used the following solution, just adding an extra % to escape in this case
`SELECT firstname, lastname FROM bf_raw.bf_user where firstname like 'A%%' limit 10`
See below:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/40442292/how-to-use-a-wildcard-in-pandas-read-sql

Should I add this to the documentation and close the ticket? Or will this be handled in an upcoming fix. Seems like there will need to be some regexing/replacing of the sql string to handle this. Thanks for your prompt response also.
I'm going to pull the branch personally but would be nice to have gifs in the PR.
Removed the `[Request for comments]` in the title as it's clear we're moving forward with this.

it seems like most entries in these tables are simple enough to have equal column widths and wrap if they overflow? also `react-virtualized` exports a utility component to measure cells (still requires fixed width or height) that you could try to leverage.

@mistercrunch how does [this](https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/blob/master/superset/sql_lab.py#L81) existing logic work , i.e., `get_session` is called by the Celery worker to get the DB session, using the configuration logic defined in `app.config`, yet the app context shouldn't be defined.
Superceeded by https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/pull/4565 and following PRs
LGTM
![spain](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/487433/38002448-4618b908-31e7-11e8-80a1-474dda31934d.gif)

The whole `conf` parsing depends on Flask's way of doing this. This predates SQL Lab and the Celery workers.

It could be nice to further dissociate the flask app from the celery worker, but currently they share their configuration which depends on Flask.

Is it a problem that the app context is defined though?
@mistercrunch I've updated the logic to pass through the rendered query to the Celery task.
It would be nice to have a unit test that would cover both `presto.latest_partition` along with impersonation.

We have a cell-measuring utils function somewhere on our side too. 

I think it gets tricky. Picture a report with a wide HDFS folder locations as in `/hive/warehouse/default/fact_rides/20180101/file234872948298` and one metric (say `megabytes`). You clearly don't want a wrapped `HDFS folder` to accommodate a 50% width metric.

Though I do like the idea of having consistently sized metrics where one metric doesn't look arbitrarily more important than another one just because the label is wider. It could be interesting to see how browsers do it (proportion based on max(width)? proportion based on avg(wdith)?). I'm guessing it's a bit fuzzy and might generally look better than a simpler `width/num_columns`.
@mistercrunch would we need to mock the Presto connection? I haven't seen any Presto specific tests.
@mistercrunch Where is the interface to the Mongo database？

I am happily using superset - and I have a calculated column on the datasource with a dimensionSpec expression that describes a query time lookup. 

Grouping works well but filtering does not on this calculated column...  Anyone succeeded in doing this? Maybe I need to update the query generator?

Finally figured setting this line to False fixes the issue. Not sure if there will be any negative consequences, as I'm sure this is set to True for a reason:
https://github.com/snowflakedb/snowflake-sqlalchemy/blob/master/base.py#L340

I saw a similar issue for Oracle (https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/pull/3775). I'm thinking this key error will arise for any dialect that uses requires_name_normalize = True, so maybe there should be a general superset fix.

@williaster thanks for all the comments- they should be addressed now.

Good callout on the PropTypes.object stragglers- I feel better now that they're cleaned up.

Duplicate of #4619

I have not had issues with this. Any format of a timestamp that works in Druid has worked in Superset for me. If you data is loading into druid with errors, then I would suggest the druid community. In your ingestion spec you can specify the timestamp format.
#4268 fixed this issue.
LGTM, I checked out the PR, built, and tested the feature in the UI. No issues. Appreciate the fix for this @Pek1s

@mistercrunch it seems after the Alembic upgrade the `allow_multi_schema_metadata_fetch` is `NULL` rather than `True` (which ensures backwards compatibility). I think you need to include logic of the form,
```
from sqlalchemy.sql import table, column

dbs = table('dbs', column('allow_multi_schema_metadata_fetch'))       
op.execute(dbs.update().values(allow_multi_schema_metadata_fetch=True))  
```

I think this results in double-checking the permission at the moment, which is an extra database round trip. I'm not sure how efficient it is either for non-all-datasource-access roles, meaning we'd pay a relatively expensive cost twice.

Currently the view is in charge of doing data access checks. Since the auth scheme here is a FAB (web framework) construct, it could be good to keep those check shallow in the stack, meaning in the view layer.

Curious to understand your use case and how the check on cache would differ from the datasource check.
![napo](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/487433/38063728-79637ba4-32af-11e8-8277-ad65428b69fb.gif)
Yes you're right there would be mocking involved. It might be tricky and out-of-scope for this PR here. Happy to merge as is.
Happy to review if you want to upstream your change.

Because it’s a fairly recent migration how do you feel about augmenting the existing migration? Alternatively you could make the default in the code  False (thus making it a breaking change) which evaluates the same as None (NULL).

I think for us, having this disabled is preferred.
comments? ideas? @graceguo-supercat @williaster @GabeLoins

@mistercrunch my other concern is if one sets `allow_multi_schema_metadata_fetch` to False or None then in essence you're disabling the caching logic provided by the [update_datasources_cache](https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/blob/master/superset/cli.py#L270) command which caches the tables associated with every schema per [here](https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/blob/master/superset/db_engine_specs.py#L431).

Sorry @mistercrunch I'm mistaken, the `update_datasource_cache` and the table caching logic is only used if `allow_multi_schema_metadata_fetch` is True, it calls the [/tables](https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/blob/master/superset/views/core.py#L1511) API endpoint with schema as NULL.

Our DBA Solved this issue.
The problem was in json Encoding. 
To fix you need to open **JSON.py**  and change 
`json.dumps(data, default=utils.json_iso_dttm_ser,encoding="latin-1")`
